Chris thanks for more so I wanted to talk a little bit about
some of the challenges and some of the things that we came up with and also talk through some of the solutions that
came about in terms of migrating such a a broad set of applications and and data centers into the cloud
a couple of high high points here uh obviously a lot of Windows 2003 for the
most part most of those were we were able to use VM import to migrate those and so for the most part that worked
successfully obviously when you're dealing with databases and other systems in a lot of cases we would set up
mirrors within AWS first so that's pretty common in a data center move you'd set up a mirror first migrate the
data that way there's a lot less downtime potentially no downtime in moving the system and so both the SQL
server and exchange environments were environments where we could set up a system ahead of time mirror them into the on-prem environment and then migrate
them so that definitely helped some of the challenges around the Linux infrastructure are just different
different distributions of Linux and making sure that we had the right Ami within Amazon to support the workloads
that were moving and so that's pretty typical just having to manage the disk
layouts and make sure that those were set up ahead of time just manage that via scripting and some other tools that
our Engineers deployed to be able to make that happen um another one I wanted to call out uh
that's pretty interesting is just the the timing around decommissioning the gear because all these systems are
integrated and it's very common in Enterprise data centers you need to be very careful about the timing in terms
of when you turn on gear in the new data center when you turn it off in the old one to make sure the systems are riding
into the right place that things are working the right way and so the dependency mapping and the timing is really really key when you're doing a
big migration like this another interesting data point with the Yamaha migration is there's quite a bit
of raw data to move within the systems themselves and so one of the things to
keep in mind when you're doing data center migrations is how much actual disk or how much data on disk do you
need to move and in lots of cases there were terabytes of data direct attached to servers or other things whether it be
databases or other things file servers that needs to be moved and obviously that takes a while to move into the
cloud and so just having a plan around that is helpful we were using Direct Connect in a gigabit connection there
but not always where you're getting that full bandwidth and just having to plan around that and making sure that we had
time to manage that connection was key so just thinking about the fact that you're moving large sets of data was not
uncommon for servers to have a terabyte or more of attached disk and so just making sure you're planning for those
things as you're moving into the cloud is key uh and I want to talk a little bit about
some of the managed Services components as well as this is sort of a key part of our business as well as we support folks that are in the cloud and one of one of
the stories that I talk about in terms of managed Services is we cover the different areas one of the things that's
interesting about uh leveraging the power of Amazon and how you can do this so in setting up disaster recovery for
some of the transactional databases we were able to use log syncing those kinds of things to keep them in sync and get
them ready but obviously the the Dr instance is not taking full load the benefit of leveraging Amazon is that
that can cost you a lot less right so in the case of Yamaha we're able to use sometimes instances as small as an M3
medium which on the Linux side is like seven cents an hour depending on the easier and as opposed to a C3 8xl which
is like 1.68 an hour so yeah you're literally talking per server a thousand dollars a month in Savings in terms of
leveraging those smaller servers during Dr and then turning them up into it
excels at 10 event and so you can have a very very quick time to recover and
still save a lot of money in terms of a Dr environment and so those types of things are things that we can help do as
